titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.42 Richmond, Va. Wednesday, February 18, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Latest from the North.
div3.p: --I have received Northern papers of the 15th instant, and send you the following summary of the news contained in them:

q.p: In the House of Representatives the Committee on Elections reported that Jennings Piggot, of N. Carolina, and J. B. McCleed and W. Wian of the 2d Congressional district, are not entitled to seats.

div3.p:
The Viceroy of Egypt has shipped 459 black soldiers (Zouaves) to Mexico, to aid Mapolson in Mexico--1,000 were promised.
They fought well in the Crimes.
Mr. Thayer demanded explanations.--They are to be put in garrison at Vera Cruz, because they are not subject to yellow fever.
The Monsieur, of Paris, January 22d, says, "this measure, adopted in a sense of humanity, cannot give rise to the least criticism." All this appears in dispatches from the American Consol (Mr. Thayer) at Alexandria, Egypt, laid before Congress.

It is said Napoleon is preparing for a forcible rupture of the blockade.
The Parvenu needs watching.
Prentice says the establishment of rebel newspapers should by all means be encouraged, for they consume a good deal of the material which would otherwise be made into Confederate notes.
It is thought that Banks's forces are about to make a forward movement at once to clear out the whole Lafourche country.

Letters from fifty leading citizens of New Orleans to members of the Confederate Government have been seized.
It was generally believed in New Orleans that Butler would return to that city, if not made Secretary of War.

Water flows through "Williams's cut," In front of Vicksburg, and a small stream had formed through the canal.
If it deepens and widens the Yankee fleets can pass down, leaving Vicksburg four miles distant.
An enthusiastic Union meeting has been held in Leavenworth, Kansas, and passed strong resolutions denouncing Northern traitors, declaring their punishment should not be imprisonment, but death.

The English Minister has made demands on the Brazilian Government which were refused, and the English Admiral, under orders of the Minister, seized several Brazilian vessels in Rio Janeiro.
The Brazilian Government refused to treat with the Minister.
There was great excitement and a mob threatened.
The Emperor addressed the people in person, promising that the honor of the nation should be maintained.
Gold was quoted at 155½ in New York on the 14th.
The Washington Chronicle says the Republicans are pledged to the salvation of the Republic at every hazard.

In the Senate, Friday, the Military Committee reported back Sumner's bill to raise 300,000 black soldiers, with the recommendation that it do not pass because the authority intended to be granted is sufficiently granted by the act of July 17, 1862.

The Legislature of Missouri has adjourned until November without electing a United States Senator.
All the candidates were emancipationist and only differed as to the manner in which they desired Missouri to be made a free State.
J. S. Phelps was the Democratic Conservative candidate, and favors emancipation because he says there is no longer any security for slave property.
Nicholas Longworth, the great Western wine grower, died in Cincinnatian the 10th, aged eighty years, and worth $15,000,000.

A Court of Inquiry is ordered to meet at Cairo to report what officers have been engaged, directly or indirectly, in traffic in cotton, whisker permits have been granted and by whom, or used Government transportation or other public property.

In the debate on the financial measures the bank features had so tight a squeeze in the Senate that when Mr. Powell asserted the superior value of local bank notes over Government paper at the financial centres, Mr. Fessenden got off some periods, assailing his loyalty in much the same style of Mark Antony's address over the body of The Senator of Kentucky was loyal, but when something was prepared to support the Government he opposed that which made loyalty practical.
So far as Powell's reply was in vindication of himself, it was triumphant.
But Fessenden succeeded in getting up a party feeling for the bank scheme.
Mr. Chandler said there were as many traitors in New York as in Southern cities, and the heart of the rebellion was in the North among the copperhead Democracy.
The prospects of the Bank in the House have been materially advanced.
Mr. Richardson, of Illinois, said that next week he should formally arraign Mr. Stanten before the Senate.
The intimation was also thrown out that the policy of the party in power was in a pacific direction.
Collsmer could not get the attention of his party as heretofore and stopped, saying that nobody was paying the least attention.
Mr. Lane asserted that Stanton was in favor of sending reinforcements and supplies to Fort Sumter, and anybody who asserts the contrary makes a false statement.
Richardson denial having made such a point, and there was so much angry gesticulation that a scene was apprehended.--After each had conferred with friends they subsided into quietness.
Lane is esteemed to have made an ungracious attempt to pick a quarrel. --Rice inquired why Stauton had not followed Cass's example and resigned when the Government refused to reinforce Sumter.

Fremont has applied for active service.
Commodores Preble and Perry have been nominated for restoration to rank.

The schooner Emma Tuttle was captured on the 27th, off Charleston.
She was taken once before, but her crew recaptured her.
Tom Thumb and his wife were publicly received at the White House Friday evening.

George Francis Train was arrested in St. Louis on the 7th, by order of Major-General Curtis, and in ten minutes escorted across the river.
No reason was assigned.
In a letter to the General had quires if it was because he alluded to the successful cotton speculations of army officers.

The negroes for the French army in Mexico were kidnapped in Egypt, says the correspondent of the London Times.
Every negro the police could lay hands on was seized and not allowed to take leave of his family.
There was an indignant protest from the British, American, and Austrian Consular and it is not likely that the second batch will be sent.

At the annual meeting of the Chambers of Commerce of Liverpool and Manchester, several members of Parliament who took part, gave it as their opinion that Parliament would be called upon early in the session to declare whether the Southern States had or had not entitled themselves to recognition.
Opposition to any intervention was generally expressed.

On Thursday, a equal of Baylor's rebel cavalry attacked a small scouting party (12) of the 12th Pennsylvania cavalry, killing one wounding two, and capturing four and several horses.
In the afternoon, near Charleston, the men and horses were recaptured, and Lieut Baylor, two men and several horses were taken.

The Heral's Winchester correspondence, of the 7th, says, fifteen picked men from the 12th Virginia regiment, dressed in U. S. uniforms, attacked the mail coach between Martinsburg and Winchester on the 6th, and captured the driver and occupants, including two staff officers.
One escaped and reported.
Two companies pursued to Millwood and recaptured their friends killing one rebel and taking another prisoner, after a desperate fight.
A Yankee lieutenant was wounded.
A neat little weekly paper has been recently started at York town. Va., by Lieut. J. H. Champion, and is called The Champion.

Cairo, Feb. 13.--The levees on the Mississippi side of the Mississippi river, twelve miles below Helena, at Yazoo Pass, have been cut by the Union forces.
They have also been out at Greenville, and on the Louisiana side, opposite Lake Previdence.
A barge loaded with coal ran the blockade Sunday.
A large part of the rebel army of Virginia have been moved to Vicksburg.

The New York Herald editorially compliments Seward's "masterly" reply to Napoleon's peace proposition, which it calls absurd, with all its "confiding generosity." Seward, although too sanguine in the outset touching the suppression of the rebellion, remains undismayed and unshaken as to the final issue; but the Administration still fails to grasp the dimensions, the difficulties, and the dangers of this rebellion.
If all were like Seward "our principal army would not now be halting midway between Washington and Richmond; our principal naval squadrons would not now be held at bay by the rebel defences at Charleston and Vicksburg; nor would the national finances, credit, and currency be reduced to the verge of ruin by wasteful extravagances, exhausting corruptions, and temporizing financial expedients." The Herald thinks the President has to fear chiefly "the danger of overwhelming discords, party divisions popular commotions, rites, and a reign of bloody anarchy in the loyal States.
" These fearful contingencies of the future are beginning to be foreshadowed a various forms of manifestations.
The Herald facetiously suggests that Seward between him and Mexico.

div4.head: European news.
div4.p:
The Elna arrived in New York early on the 13th. The Emperor of France was endeavoring to perfect a new plan for mediation or intervention in the war affairs of the United States with, it was said, the view of promoting a peace between the North and South. M. Drouyn de L'Huys had addressed a circular to the French Ministers in London, Berlin, Vienna, and St. Petersburg, directing them to "sound" the feeling of the Cabine's of these countries upon the propriety of tendering simple counsels to the "belligerent parties in Washington and Richmond," advising them to name commissioners charged to examine, "with or without an armistice, the basis of a settlement.
Articles in the special newspaper organs of the Emperor, the Empress, and Prince Napoleon, show that France is exceedingly anxious to bring about a peace in America, in the interest of her cotton manufacturers and the elevation and extension of her political prestige on this side of the Atlantic.
The new Archbiship of Paris, in a letter addressed to the people of his late see, strikes an ecclesiastical blow at Russia and England for refusing to join Napoleon in his first effort at mediation.

The London Shipping Gazette, of the 29th of January, inquires what will be Napoleon's alternative if his latest project for an allied interference is rejected by the other great Powers?
The Gazette says: "It may be taken for granted that the offered negotiation will be rejected at Washington;" and asks, "what follows the compulsory cessation of hostilities, or a maritime was with the North?
Can this country afford to let the French Emperor proceed alone in his American policy?
or, is he acting upon an understanding with Her Majesty's Government? "

The steamer Georgiana, the tender of the Alabama went to sea on the 24th January, from Holyhead, England, bound for Nassau.
She had a formidable crew of rough looking men, of almost every European nationality.
She mounts 28 guns, and carries out a quantity of tea and other necessaries for the use of the crow of the Alshama.
A letter says, "She is bound for America, and looks just the thing for running the blockade."
The clipper Eilsa Bonsal arrived at Liverpool, from Nassau on the 26th ult, with 1,500 bales of cotton brought by the "blockade breakers."

The Russian military conscription in Poland cause a national military revolution.
The Poles killed all the soldiers found billeted in houses, and destroyed telegraph wires at Warsaw.
Two thousand conscripts deserted.
Conflicts had taken place.
The whole kingdom of Poland was declared in a state of siege. "Warsaw in great," but it is not certain that any decided impression has been made on the insurrection.
The London Star has received the following from its special Paris correspondent:

The French Government is on the point of intervening as pacificator between the Federal and Confederates.
In anticipation of late events in America, M. Mercer has received instructions to act as a mediator between the belligerents, and M. Drouyn de L'huys is preparing a note that will be shortly transmitted to Mr. Seward, in which a compromise will be recommended.
The London Shipping Gazette remarks, that should the Emperor a proposal be acted, he has left himself, apparently, but an alternative to recognize the South and raise the Southern blockade.

The New York Herald heads an extract from the Paris co resplendence of the London Post with this caption: "Napoleon's Hopes of an-Alliance with Jeff Davis." The correspondent says the officers agree that France will bold Mexico; and if so, France will assuredly find it convenient to make an alliance with the Southern Republic of America.
The distress in Ireland is every day tending more severe among laborers small farmers, etc., to their actual pauperism, exile, or death.
The Liverpool cotton market, on the 20th ult., were irregular, and prices easier.

div3.head: [General Newspaper Dispatch.]
div3.p: --The Washington Chronicle, of the 15th, has been received by flag of truce.

Dispatches from the U. S. Consul at Alexandria, Egypt, and Minister Dayton, were laid before the U. S. Senate on the 14th, to the effect that the Viceroy of Egypt has furnished the Emperor of France with several hundred negro soldiers to join the military expedition against Mexico.
The Moniteur says they will garrison Cruz because not subject to yellow fever.
The Consul at Alexandria demanded an explanation from the Viceroy.
The European Consuls General have telegraphed for instructions from their Governments.

The Empire City, from New Orleans on the 4th, reports that Banks's forces, after several months' drilling, were in a condition to take the field.
It was thought a forward movement would be made at once to clear the whole Lafourche country.
A second regiment of blacks is to be formed at Port Royal, with Montgomery, of Kansas leader.

Lieut Pitch, commanding fleet on Cumberland river, in his official report of the fight at Fort Donelson says 4,500 rebels, under Forrest.
Wheeler, and Wharton, were cut up and routed by gunboats, and thwarted in their purpose of capturing the Federal at Dover, who were cut of ammunition and entirely surrounded.
One hundred and forty rebels were buried on the field, and the wounded were left in the hands of the Federal.

Gen. Francis Train was arrested at St. Louis by order of Gen. Curtis commanding the department of Missouri, and ordered to leave St. Louis at once.
Cause unknown.
The Federal have cut the levee on the Mississippi at Yazoo Pass, Greenville and opposite Lane Providence.

div4.head: The capture of the U. S. Vessels off Sabine Pass.
div4.p:
The Houston Telegraph, of the 23d, contains a full account of the capture of the two blockaders off Sabine Pass, Texas.
Our force consisted of two little steamers, the Bell and Uncle Ben, manned by 300 sharpshooters, under Major Watkins.
The Telegraph says:

q.p:
On the morning of the 21st the steamers got up steam and started for the bar. They discovered, at about twelve miles distance, two vessels, which proved to be the brig-of war Morning Light, mounting eight 32 pounders and one rifle gun, and a schooner, (name unknown) mounting two fine Dathigrens.
The Morning Light is the same vessel that destroyed Winston's salt works.
Her men, it will be remembered, were thoroughly punished in that affair.
The moment the vessels discovered them they up sail and ran to sea to escape our steamers.
All steam was at once put on, and an exciting chase commenced.
At about ten o'clock, the chase having continued about fifteen miles, the Bell got in range, and the Davis Guards let fly their first gun at the Morning Light.
The chase continued for some miles further, giving our boys time to fire ten or twelve shots, which took effect in the brig. The brig answered, but was unable to let the Bell at all.

div4.p:
Having now approached to within good musket range, it did not take long for the riflemen to clear the enemy a dock.
Before the had her colors were hanted down, and our boys took undisputed possession.
It did not require long to take the schooner.

Both vessels were carried to the bar, but a Federal steamer coming in night before the Morning Light could be lightened sufficiently to go over she was burnt, but the schooner carried inside — The following to the report of Lieut. Reed of the U. S. gun boat New London, who was going to the relief of the blockaders when they were destroyed.

At 12 M., on the 23d of January he discovered the Morning Light.
A steamer was just leaving her, and in a few moments the former was discovered to be on fire.
The Cayuga was ordered forward, but it was impossible to save her. The fire was started in the part of the ship.

The towed her in ten feet of water, perhaps with the hope of getting her over the bar into the Pass. Four of her guns were discharged by the heat, three on the port side and one on the star board side, the latter had fallen into the hold, and the out just above her copper, one boat being the time.
Two of her shells exploded.
The had undoubtedly removed the powder from the magazines as no explosions took place except the guns and shells.

It is thought that the enemy did not get any of the guns of the Morning Light.
As to the schooners Rachael and Veracity, the former, Lt. Reed had learned, has escaped; the latter was captured with the Morning Light.

div4.head: in Baltimore.
div4.p: The following Extract from the Baltimore Gazette, of the 11th instant, gives a fair sample of the rule that unhappy city is under:

Yesterday morning, near the close of business hours at the Corn and Flour Exchange, a cavalryman, armed with a sword and revolver, entered the room, and a crossing one of the members, desired to know who was the clerk.
He was at once directed to Mr. John P. Paca, the Secretary of the Association, from whom he demanded a flat of the contributors for the relief of the Confederate prisoners at Cairo.
Mr. P. Informed the dragoon that the list had not been nor was it in his possession, and further that it had merely been placed temporarily on the desk on Saturday.
The soldier then demanded to know at what hour business would close, and remarked that his instructions were to remain there until the business was over for the day, which he did, being still seated on one of the lounges after the hour of noon had arrived, and long after the last member had departed.
There was no interruption to business whatever, neither was there any unusual excitement, the members dispersing at the usual time and not before.

div4.head: Gen. Butler for Charleston.
div4.p: A Washington dispatch in the New York Times says:

q.p:
The plan of sending Gen. Butler to Charleston, so vehemently denied by one of your contemporaries awhile since, is seriously debated, and is one of the propositions intended to head off the strong popular demand for his installment in the War Office Gen. Butler has given his views to the Government to a system of operations from that city as a and his plan is characteristic of his genius.
Still it is probable that the Government has as yet reached no conclusion in the matter.

div4.head: Congressional Poetry.
div4.p: Hon. Mr. Cox, of Ohio, delivered a very strong speech in the Yankee Congress last week in favor of peace, and closed it with the following poem — We rather think "Caroline" won't find it convenient to "remember the pathway:"

lg.l: she has gone — she has left us in passion and pride--
our stormy browed sister, so long at our side!
she has torn her own star from our firmament's glow,
and turned on her brother the face of a foe!
O. Caroline, Caroline, child of the sun.
we can never forget that our hearts have been out;
our foreheads both sprinkled in liberty's name,
from the fountain of blood with the river of flame!
you were always too ready to fire at a touch;
but we said "She is hasty — she does not mean much."
we have scowled when you uttered some turbulent threat;
but Friendship still whispered--"Forgive and forget."

has our love all died out?
have its altars grown cold?
has the curse come at last which the fathers foretold?
then nature must teach us the strength of the chain.
that her petulant children would sever in twain
they may fight till the buzzards are gorged with their spoil.
'Till the harvest grows black as it rots in the soil,
'Till the wolves and the catamounts droop from their caves.
and the shark tracks the pirate, the lord of the waves.

in vain is the strife!
when its fury is past.
their fortunes must flew in one channel at last; [Cheers;]
as the torrents that rush from the mountains of snow.
Roll mingled in peace through the valley below.
our Union is river, lake, ocean, and sky;
man breaks not the medal when God cuts the die?
though darkened with sulphur, though cloven with steel,
the blue arch will brighten, the waters will heal.
O, Caroline, Caroline, child of the sun,
there are battles with fate that can never be won?
the star flowering banner must never be buried.

for its blossoms of light are the hope of the world!
[Applause]

l.hi:
Go, then, our rash sister!
afar and aloof,
Run wild in the sunshine away from our roof;

lg.l: But when your heart aches, and your rest have grown sore,

Remember the pathway that leads to our door!
[Applause]

div3.head:
From Fredericksburg.
[from our Own correspondent]
div3.p:
While I write the screaming car-whistle of the Yankees is sounding to-night, like "the shriek of a scalded fiend," across the Tappahannock.
Bugles and drums keep up the din, and assure us of continued activity and "merriment." The balloon was also up this evening higher than usual — perhaps to see the retreating Yankees on the Potomac.
They have also gone down the Tappahannock--70,000 one picket said this morning.
They are certainly building a causeway through a marsh nine miles below, on the other side, just as they did when Burnside went up and got stuck in the mud. Families below, immediately opposite them, on this side, are moving further off. Which way are they going?
The light of probably some other dwelling-house "accidentally" consumed, which illuminated the Northern sky about 9 P. M., "throws no light" upon the question.
I expect General Lee knows all about it, and so I shall sleep quietly.

Gen. Patrick came over in the flag of truce boat this morning, and said the Phillips House had been Gen. Stoneman's headquarters, but he had moved out because Honker wanted it for a hospital.
A stove was left in the second story with fire in it, from which the house caught fire, and was consumed.
He had tried to save the furniture, and had it brought to the Lacy House but some of it was missing.
Of course!
There will be many things "missing" when the Yankees leave Starford, but they won't be "missed."

Gen. Patrick brought over Gen. Stonewall Jackson's Chaplain, who had been captured but Gen. Barksdale could not receive him without General Lee's permission, and he had to return to his missionary labors among the heathens on the other side.

P. S.--17th.
Snow this morning is falling fast.
Already (9 A. M.) two inches deep, and looks as if it would snow all day.

div4.p:
--Met at noon. Mr. Johnson, President pro tempore, in the chair.
Prayer by the Rev. Dr. Moore.

A message from the Governor, in response to a resolution, acquainted the Senate with the extent of the Partisan Bangers organization, the number of companies in the service, number of commissioned officers, and what sums have been paid them out of the Paymaster's department.
It was stated that the sum of $29,395,57 had been disbursed in their payment.
Referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, and ordered to be printed.

Resolutions of Inquiry and Expediency.--By Mr. Alderson: Instructing the Committee on Finance and Claims to inquire into the expediency of reporting a bill releasing the representative of John M. Alderson, deceased late Sheriff of Greenbrier, from the collection of militia fines placed in the hands of his deputy a short time prior to his death.
By Mr. Whittle: Instructing the Committee for Courts of Justice to inquire into the expediency of enacting such laws consistent with the Constitution and laws of the Confederate States as may be necessary to reduce to slavery any free negro residing in the United States who may be found within the limits of this Commonwealth.
By Mr. Lynch: Instructing the Committee on Finance to inquire into the expediency of allowing corporations indebted to the State to liquidate the principal before the same be due, or any part thereof, and stop the interest thereon.

Committee Bills Reported.--A bill refunding to William M. Bume, Sheriff of Fauquier, damages paid by him as such.
A bill to amend and re-enact the fourth and fifth sections of chapter eighty-seventh of the Code.

Disposal of Bills.--The bill to increase the allowance for the board and lodging of jurors in criminal cases was passed.
The bill authorizing impressments for the support of soldiers' families and other poor, during the war, was defeated.
The bill making an appropriation to the Central Lunatic Asylum was amended by a "ryder," and referred to the Finance Committee.
The bill transferring the State Line troops to the Confederate Government was taken up its provisions variously amended, ordered to be engrossed, read the third time, and laid on the table.
The resolutions of Mr. Collier in relation to the impressment in Saulsbury, N. C., of one Collina, a citizen of Prince George county, were passed by the Senate.
Adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Doggett.
A message was received from the Governor relative to the compensation of agents for the distribution of salt; which was read, and on motion of Mr. Barbour, referred to the Committee on Salt.

The bill empowering county courts to impress articles of prince necessity for the use of citizens in certain care; which was under consideration at the hour of adjournment yesterday, was taken up, amended, and ordered to its engrossment.
The bill imposing taxes for the support of Government heretofore made the order of the day for to-day, was taken up and considered.

During the pendency of this bill, the hour of 12 o'clock having arrived, the processes issued against Joseph E. Orenshaw and George Whitfield for falling to appear before the Committee on Extortion, when summoned so to do, came up for consideration.

Mr. Hopkins stated that Mr. Crenshaw was then present in the House.
That he was laboring under severe indisposition, and from a conversation had with him he was satisfied that his non- compliance with the summons of the committee was owing to no want of respect for the authority of the House, and that he was prepared to obey sold summons at any time the committee may require.
He therefore moved that he be discharged, which was agreed to.

Mr. Whitfield was reported to be in the Hall, and was taken to the bar of the House, where the usual oath having been administered by the Speaker, he took the witnesses' stand to answer questions propounded by the chairman of the Committee on Extortion, and "show cause why he should not be fined and imprisoned," when the following colloquy transpired:
Mr. Hopkins.--Will you state to the House your reasons for failing to appear before the Committee on Extortion when summoned so to do?

Mr. Whitfield.--I was sick, and acted under the advice of my physician.
I had no purpose to treat with disrespect the authority of the House.
Mr. Hopkins.--Why didn't you send an affidavit to the committee to that effect?
Mr. Whitfield.--I didn't know that it was necessary.
Mr. Hopkins--Were you so much indisposed as to apprehend any serious consequences from venturing out?
Mr. Whitfield.--I don't know that it would have killed me.
Mr. Forbos here offered the following resolution:

Resolved, That further proceedings under the summons issued on yesterday, directing Geo. Whitfield to appear at the bar of this House to show cause why he should not be final and imprisoned for contempt of the summon therein set forth, be deferred until Tuesday, the 24th day of February.

Mr. Hunter thought the proceedings were somewhat singular.
The witness had appeared at the bar of the House, as summoned to do, and fully purged himself of all intention of contempt or disrespect, and he therefore moved to amend the resolution of Mr. Forbes by moving that the witness be discharged.

The motion gave rise to some discussion, participated in by Messrs. Forbes, Hunter, Barbour, Robertson, and others, when the previous question was called, and the vote being upon the amendment of Mr. Hunter, that gentleman demanded the ayes and noes, which resulted — ayes 39, noes 52.
The amendment having been rejected, the vote recurred upon the resolution of Mr. Forbes, which was adopted.
The witness was then released in accordance with the provisions of the resolution just adopted.

The further consideration of the tax bill was then resumed and continued until 3 o'clock, when, on motion of Mr. Hunter, it was made the order of the day for to-morrow at 12 o'clock, and from day to day thereafter until disposed of.

Mr. Hunter, from the Committee on Courts, submitted a report adverse to a sine ute adjournment on the 26th inst.; also, declaring the present session of the General Assembly not to be a continuation of the session of May last.
A motion to print the reports was lost.
Mr. Robertson submitted a resolution, which was agreed to inquiring into the expediency of providing for giving more publicity to the laws.
On motion of Mr. Fleming, the House adjourned.
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by Mr. Hunter, of Va.
On motion of Mr. Mitchell, of Arkansas, the Senate proceeded to elect by ballet a member to fill a vacancy in the Committee on Hospitals and Mr. Capirton, of Va., was chosen.

Mr. Sparrow, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back the message of the President transmitting an estimate for incidental and contingent expenses of the army and War Department until 30th June. Referred to Finance Committee.

Mr. Sparrow reported back from the Military Committee, with a recommendation that it do not pass the bill to amend an act entitled an act to provide for transportation of persons who have been mustered into the service for the war. He also reported back from same committee the bill authorizing the discharge of certain civil officers from the military service of the Confederate States, with certain amendments, which they recommend do pass.
The President announced the Exemption bill as the unfinished business of the previous day. It was amended in sundry particulars and debated till the hour of adjournment.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Mr. Wise.
Mr. Gaither, of N. C., presented resolutions adopted by the General Assembly of that State, vindicating the loyalty of the State and its General Assembly.

Mr. Gaither addressed the House on the subject of these resolutions, and alluded to the present position of his State--reviewing her action from the commencement of the war to the present time.--He repelled the slanderous accusations that had been brought against her. Her devotion to the cause in which we are engaged was not surpassed by that of any other State in the Confederacy.

Mr. Lander, of N. C., also addressed the House with reference to the resolutions, and said that their adoption by the Legislature of North Carolina was, in his opinion, unnecessary.
His State had already vindicated her loyalty by her sixty thousand troops now in the field.
Further remarks upon the same subject were made by Messrs Gaither and McLean.
Mr. Boyce, of S. C., introduced for reference a bill to establish a port of entry at Columbia, S. C. Referred to Committee on Commerce.

Mr. Miles, of S. C., introduced a bill to regulate the navigation of the Confederate States, and to establish direct trade with foreign nations.
Referred to Committee on Commerce.

Mr. Miles also introduced a resolution that the Government of the Confederate States has witnessed with feelings of no ordinary gratification the loyalty and good faith of the larger portion of its Indian allies west of the State of Arkansas; and, further, that no effort of the Confederate Government shall be spared to protect them fully in all their rights, and to assist them in defending their country against the encroachments of all enemies.
Referred to Committee on Indian Affairs.

Mr. Miles also offered a resolution that 5,000 copies of the Journal of the Convention which framed the Provisional and Permanent Constitutions of the Confederate States, together with the Journal of the Provisional Congress, be published for the use of this House, to be distributed equally among the members: Provided, That each member of the Provisional Congress shall receive two copies of said journals, and the President of the Confederate States and each of the Governors of the several States five copies each.
Referred to Committee on Printing.

Mr. Atkins, of Tenn, offered a resolution that the President be requested to direct.
Adjutant General Cooper to call upon Lieut. Gen. Polk for his report (if it has not already been received) of the operations of the corps d'armce under his command in the battle of Shiloh; and that it, together with the report of Brig. Gen. Preston Smith of the part performed by his command in the engagement at Richmond, Ky., be printed.
Mr. Foote, of Tenn, moved to amend the resolution as follows, which was agreed to:
"And also the several official reports heretofore made by Gen. B. R. Johnson, of the battles participated in by him, including those of Fort Donelson and Shiloh."

Mr. Foote also offered a resolution that the Committee on the Quartermaster's Department be instructed to inquire into the case of Quartermaster Wood, as set forth in the letter of H. P. Taylor which was presented with the resolution.
Agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Kenner, of La., the House went into secret session upon the special order, being the bill reported from the Committee of Ways and Means, entitled a bill for funding the currency.

div3.head: "The Northwest"
div3.p: As this portion of the present United States is attracting much attention, just now, the following tables, compiled from the census of 1850, showing the place of birth of the population of two of the Northwestern States, may prove interesting:

Illinois--Alabama, 1325; Arkansas, 727; California, 3; District of Columbia, 226; Connecticut, 6,899; Delaware, 1,397; Florida, 23; Georgia, 1,34; Illinois, 343,618; Indiana, 30,953; Iowa, 1,511; Kentucky, 49,588; Louisiana, 480; Maine, 3,693; Maryland, 6,898; Massachusetts, 9,280; Michigan, 2,158; Mississippi, 490; Missouri, 7,228; New Hampshire, 4,288; New Jersey, 6,843; New York, 67,180; North Carolina, 13,851; Ohio, 64,219; Pennsylvania, 37,949; Rhode Island, 1,051; South Carolina, 4,161; Tennessee, 32,303; Texas, 63; Vermont, 11,381; Virginia, 24,697; Wisconsin, 1,005, England, 18,628; Scotland, 4,661; Wales, 572; Ireland, a7,78d; Prussia, 288; rest of Germany, 38,100; Austria, 65; Holland, 220; Norway, 2,415; France, 3,396; British America, 10,699; other countries, 3,705.
Total native, 736,931, of which after deducting those born in the State, 148,730 from other free States, 144,583 from slaveholding States.
Total foreign, 110,593.
Unknown, 3,946.
Total white and free colored population, 851,470.

Indiana.--Alabama 395; Arkansas, 151; District of Columbia, 227; Connecticut, 2,485; Delaware, 2,737; Florida, 21; Georgia, 761; Illinois, 4,173; Indiana, 511,079; Iowa, 407; Kentucky, 68,651; Louisiana, 321; Maine, 976; Maryland, 10,177; Massachusetts, 2,678; Michigan, 1,817; Mississippi, 287; Missouri, 1,006; New Hampshire, 886; New Jersey, 7,887; New York, 24,310; North Carolina, 33,175; Ohio, 120,193, Pennsylvania, 44,245; Rhode Island, 433; South Carolina, 4,061 Tennessee, 12,734; Texas, 41; Vermont, 3,183; Virginia, 41,819; Wisconsin, 99; Great Britain and Ireland, 19,847; Germany, 19,324; France, 2,279, British America, 1,878; other countries, 1,098.
Total native, 931,392, of which, after deducting those born in the State, 213,955, from other "free States," 176,318 from slaveholding States.
Total foreign, 54,426 Unknown, 2,598.
Total white and free colored population, 988,416.
The ratio per cent of the foreign born to the whole population in Illinois is 12.19, in Indiana, 5.51.
The following is the vote of these two States in the last Presidential election:
Total for Lincoln, 294,563, total against Lincoln, 287,357.

div3.head: How to Straighten a Nigro's Wool.
div3.p:
--The New York Tribune states that Fred. Douglas gave a lecture or speech at the Cooper Institute, in New York, on Friday night, on the President's Proclamation.
Among other things he said: "Since the uttering of this proclamation I have grown taller and felt whiter, and comb my hair with much less difficulty."

div3.head: Damages Claimed.
div3.p: --It is said the owners of the bark Parker Cook, of Boston, burnt by the Alabama, have made a claim on the United States Government for $9,000 damages for the loss occasioned by the destruction of that vessel.
The Fortress Monroe correspondent of the New York Herald has discovered that Stonewall Jackson has gone to Tennessee to reinforce Joe Johnston.
A duel was fought at West Point, Ga, on the 10th instant, between Michael and -- Goldsborough, in which the former was killed at the first fire.

div3.head:
Important from Charleston.
Proclamation from General Beauregard.
div3.p: --The following Proclamation from Gen. Beauregard will appear in the papers to-morrow:

div4.head:
Headq's Dept of S. C., Ga. & Fla.,
Charleston, Feb. 18, 1863.
div4.p: It has become my solemn duty to inform the authorities and citizens of Charleston and Savannah that movements of the enemy's fleet indicate an early land and naval attack on one or both cities, and to urge that persons unable to take an active part in the struggle shall retire.

It is hoped, however, that this temporary reparation of some of you from your homes will be made without alarm or undue haste, thus showing that the only feeling which animates you in this hour of supreme trial is the regret of being unable to participate in the defence of your homes; your altars, and the graves of your kindred.

Carolinian and Georgians!
The hour is at hand to prove your country's cause.
Let all able- bodied men from the seaboard to the mountains rush to arms.
Be not too exacting in the choice of weapons.
Pikes and scythes will do for exterminating your enemies; spades and shovels for protecting your fire sides.
To arms, follow citizens!
Come to share with us our danger, our brilliant success, or our glorious death.
div4.closer:
(Signed) G. T. Beauregard,
General Comm'g.
Official:--J. M. Otey, A. A. G.
Final preparations for the expected attack are being rapidly perfected. Troops and people are calm and confident.

div3.head: Exparte Theodore Whitman upon a writ of Habeas corpus.
div3.p: --This case, involving the right of the President to declare Martial law over the city of Richmond, to prescribe offences, and to punish violations of his orders committed by citizens, by arraignment and trial before Court-martial, which had some time before been very elaborately argued before the Court by the Judge Advocate, Robert Onic, Esq., for the Court- Martial, and by Judge Crump for the petitioner, was decided yesterday by Judge Wm H. Lyons, of the Hustings Court, in favor of the petitioner.

The Court held that the power to declare Martial law under the Constitution and laws of the Confederacy did not belong to the President, and that Congress had no authority to confer such power upon him; that the authority to suspend the writ of habeas corpus did not carry with it the right to declare Martial law; that Martial law was an arbitrary and dictatorial power, which might be exercised by a Commander-in-Chief over his camp or elsewhere at his peril, and that neither the Constitution or the laws sanctioned or justified such a stretch of power; that the Congress might indemnify the Commander-in-Chief for powers thus unlawfully assumed, but the Courts could neither recognize or sanction it; that our Government was one of Constitution and laws as well in time of war as in time of peace; that the Constitution limited and defined the powers of the President and the Congress, and that no powers belonged to either which was not expressly conferred by that instrument.
That courts martial have exclusive and restricted jurisdiction over soldiers and others belonging to the army; that their functions were circumscribed by law and confined entirely to those who were in the military service; and that, therefore, they had no right to try a citizen not connected with the army, who was under the Constitution entitled to trial by jury for every offence against the laws and therefore the custody in which the petitioner was held was illegal, and he was ordered to be discharged; but the Court held him to ball to answer before the Grand Jury the imputed offence — calling liquor.

div3.head: City Council.
div3.p:
--There was a called meeting of this body held at the City Hall at 4 o'clock yesterday evening.
Present, David J. Saunders and a quorum.
The meeting was called for the purpose of considering the new tax bill.
After a brief allusion to some of its provisions it was laid on the table and ordered to be printed.
It is probable from the temper of the Council on the subject, that the taxes for the present year will be raised twenty percent, at least, on real estate.
Other articles of property may be raised in proportion, but no intimation has been thrown out by which the rate can be judged of. A report on small pox generally was read from Dr. Albert Snead, Health Officer, by which it would appear that disease was abating its ravages.

div3.head: Robbery on Main street.
div3.p:
--On Wednesday night, the merchant tailoring establishment of Messrs Beers & Spillman, on Main street between 13th and 14th, was broken open, and several articles of valuable clothing stolen therefrom, including a uniform coat, a pair of fine cloth pantaloons, and an elegant overcoat.
The glass door of the store was broken by a brick and the entrance effected through the spectre.

div3.head: Abolition prisoners arrived.
div3.p:
--Twenty-four Abolition prisoners of war arrived at the Libby prison yesterday.
There was only one commissioned officer among them.
These followers of old Abe were captured on the Tappahannock, in Fauquier co, on Saturday last, after a brisk skirmish, by Lieut. Shiver and Serg't Mikler, of Col. Butler's cavalry.
There are now in the Libby prison about 500 men, including 65 deserters from the Yankee army.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p: --Judge Wm, H. Lyons presiding.--Several cares were disposed of to day, the Court having gone to work in good earnest to dispose of the large number of cases before it, and the juries sworn in the several cases reaming equally determined to do their duty.

John Boyd a young white man, said to belong to the plug-ugly crowd was set to the bar, charged with picking the pocket of Arman M. Hancock a soldier, of $28; near the Varieties, Franklin street, a few months since.
It was contended by Mr. Lucas, counsel for the prisoner, that Hancock was intoxicated, and did not know who robbed him.--The Attorney for the Commonwealth sought to rebut this supposition by showing that Hancock, immediately on discovering the abstraction of the funds, had seized Boyd, charged him with the larceny, called the watch, and did not release his hold until the accused was in custody of the watchmen.
The case being given to the jury they retired, and returned with a verdict of guilty, ascertaining the term of confinement in the Penitentiary at two years. The defendant was called to the bar for sentence, which was passed in accordance with the finding of the jury.

John Phelps, alias John Dunbar, was next tried for stealing a horse from Lieut. Vincent Matthewson.
It appeared that defendant and James M. Elmore took the horses from near a military camp on the Brook road, and that on their attempting to go to Hanover by the same road, they rode by a camp where the owners of the animals happened to be. The horses were recognized and pursuit mace, which continued for 23 miles, resulting in the apprehension of both of the defendants.
The case being given to the jury, they returned a verdict of guilty, with two years in the Penitentiary.

John McGinness was next arraigned and tried for stealing a horse from Lieut. John S. Dorsett; of Hawley's cavalry company.
It appeared that he stole the horse from the camp below.
Richmond, and arriving here sold it to Mr. Thos. Duke for $65. Verdict guilty, with five years in the State's prison.
Defendant is yet to be tried for stealing a horse belonging to Capt. Hawley, which he also brought to this city and disposed of.
The Court sits at 10½ o'clock this morning.

Mayor's Court. Tuesday, Feb'y 17. --Wm. Edwards charged with stealing a pair of saddle-bags, two shirts four pairs of socks, and a pair of spurs, the whole valued at $25 from D. Peter Holliday, at the Ballard House, under went an examination; which resulted in his discharge.

The case of Henry, slave of Wm. Catlett, charged with stealing a trunk, together with its contents, valed at $2,000, the property of Capt. Henry Taylor, was partly heard, and continued on account of the absence of important witnesses.
Milly, slave o' Benj. Leake, charged with stealing sundry articles of wearing apparel from Mrs. Agnes Biglow, was tried and acquitted.

John Otley, arrested at the new Richmond Theatre, on Monday night, on the charge of interfering with the doorkeeper, obstructing the entrance to the establishment, and refusing to leave when politely requested so to do, was required to give security for his good behavior.
Peitiaux, slave of Wm. R. Robinson, found by the watchmen without a pass was ordered 10 lashes by the Mayor.

Attention is called to the advertisement, in another column, of Mr. Herbert Tompkins, who has been despoiled of some of his wearing apparel.
To ensure his escape from the disease which endears the stolen articles to Mr. T., the thief should immediately return them as desired.

div3.head: By James M. Tayler & son, Auct's.
div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of 85 Acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep Run Turnpike.
At Auction.--As administrator of John Ford dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the leads of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms, Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico so and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. S. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Commissioner's Sale of Lot and Dwelling Hose in the city of Richmond.
div3.p:
--As Commissioner acting under a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond pronounced on the 7th day of February, 1863, in the case of Guardian, vs. Smith and others, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, beginning at 4 o'clock P. M., the property in said, with a wooden dwelling-house and other improvements thereon, fronting 30 feet on the East line of 2d street, between Lee and M. sts.
running back.
120 feet.

Terms--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 month, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until all the purchase money be paid and a conveyance directed by the whole purchase money in cash.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
H. R. Howison, Comm'r.
Sale conducted by Williamson & Co. Auct. fe 17

div3.head: Beautiful improved farm, near Charlottesville, and twelve or fifteen Negroes, for Sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarie, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs Crawford and als," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the premieres, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day,) a beautiful estate, known as Meadow Clerk, containing about 660 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abundance of timber; is smooth and gently undulating, susceptible of a high degree of improvement; has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well act in old grass yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling-house, and all the necessary out houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same thus and place, 12 or 15 likely Negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Mitch Cows, &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.

Commissioner's Sale of A Half Acree Lot, No. 28, in Dval's Addition, at the corner of St.
Stephen and Charity sts.--As-Commissioner of the Circuit Court of Richmond appointed by a decree entered on the 12th of February, 1863, in the case of Coleman against Halt, & c., I shall proceed to sel, at public auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, 25th Feby, 1863 at 4 o'clock P. M., the above valuable half-acre Lot, fronting 144 feet on the west side of st street, running back on the south side of street 129 feet, and adjoining the residence of Thos C.

Terms.--One-third interest added, and title retained until order of the Court.
The taxes for 1863 to the purchaser.
div3.closer:
H. R. Goleman, Com'r.
Sale conducted by & Apperson, Auctioners. fe 14

div3.p:
Commissioner's Sale of Land in Hanover county, 1½ miles from Hanover C. H. and one mile of the Virginia Central Railroad.--Pursuant to a decree of the County Court of Hanover, pronounced on the 24th day of December, 1863, in the suit of Tally, &c., vs. Wingfield, I shall proceed to sell upon the premises, on Wednesday, the 4th day of March next the tract of Land in the bill mentioned, containing about 200 a cree, adjoining the lands of J. Z. Wingfield Wm. F. Wickham, B. Wingfield, and others and to the place on which Joe Wingfield, dec'd lately resided, about 1½ miles from the Court House, and one mile from the Virginia Central Railroad.
The building consists of a two story Dwelling, in good repair, and all necessary out buildings.
About one-third of the land is cleared, a large portion of which is in low grounds.
Of the weed land a large portion is in original growth.
The timber on the land will more than pay for it.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance in 12 months, with interest from day of sale or the whole in cash, at the option of the purchase, the to be retained until the further order of the Court.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 42, page 2.

div3.head: Resistances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Souther Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch. Richmond, Virginia," ad scaled with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the came to any agents of the Southern Express Company, ad take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 15,00 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: A long War.
div3.p:
The correspondence between Seward and Dayton — of which we gave an abstract yesterday — is well calculated to dispel the illusion under which many of us have been laboring, that the war is to be over in any very short time.
Seward evinces a determination to prosecute it as long as he shall have power to raise a man or a dollar; and in order that there may be no mistake as to his intentions on the part of foreign Governments, he proceeds to give a picture of Yankee prospects and Yankee success, which, if it were true, would not justify him in sheathing the sword until he had absolutely crushed the South.
According to him, one-half of the South is already conquered, and his invincible Yankees are preparing to put a quietus upon the other half.
Not a word is said of the humiliating defeats and disgraceful routs which constitute so large a portion of Yankee history within the last nine months. They are passed over as occurrences that are inevitable in the progress of any war, however successful its termination.
But it is sufficiently apparent that he does not dream of giving up the contest, and we are rejoiced that he has let us see what his views and objects actually are.--Nothing less than his evidence could ever cure our people of the delusion to which they cling with an obstinacy resembling the grasp of death.

So far from being about to end, we believe that the war is about to assume a shape more terrible than it has ever yet presented.
The Yankee armies were never so large as they are now, and they never threatened us at so many important points before.
It is well for this fact to be thoroughly understood.
It is all important for individuals, as well as communities, always to look their situation fully in the face, that they may know how they stand, and what they can do in the crisis.
We shall beat the Yankees, we believe.
We have always beaten them whenever they have given us a chance.
Unless in the case of an isolated position — as at Donelson and Roanoke Island — or where they have been enabled to bring their superior fleet to bear upon us, they have never been able to contend with us. We have rarely ever encountered them, when they had not at least three to one against us, and if none of, our numerous victories have been pushed to a satisfactory consummation, it is because of that very inferiority of numbers.
We will continue to beat them.
But the time has not yet come for them to give up the contest.

div3.head: Caleb Cushing.
div3.p: This man is reported to have said, in a late meeting at Boston, the object of which was to take into consideration the best plan for settling Florida with Yankees--

"The question had frequently been asked him, 'how will you govern the rebel States if you conquer them?' He thought if they were whipped, the rebel States would give up, as many others had done before them.
The proper way to secure this result was by earnestly supporting the Government of the country, and lending it every aid to put down the rebellion.
We had failed thus far by the failure to recognize the black element in the South and the white loyal element as those to be first consulted in establishing the policy of the country.
We should have consulted the wishes of these people, instead of listening to the soft blandishments of such men as Wickliffe, of Kentucky, or Governor Stanley, of North Carolina, who in his opinion, were just as ready as Jefferson Davis to cut our throats.
[Applause.] If it be necessary to bury three hundred thousand slaveholders to save twenty-five millions of men, let the slaveholders be buried by all means.
[Applause] A rebel has no right to his life, to his property, or to liberty.
That is the plain law. Let us, therefore, carry it out. If not, what is to become of the loyal men of the South?
It was nothing to him who was put in the place of the slaveholder — a black man or a white.
[Applause] There was nothing to prevent the operatives of Lancashire or the Germans from participating in this movement.--[Applause.] Those who in Europe are complaining that their operatives are unemployed should send their laborers here, and we will give them land in abundance and enough to do. [Applause.]"

This man Cushing was, but a short time ago, the most Southern of all the Southerners not only in Boston, but in North America. Mr. Yancey, or President Davis, could not match his fiery goal in the Southern cause.
In a speech made in Boston shortly after the election of Lincoln, he denounced Senator Wilson and the whole Abolition party of the North, ascribing to them all the evil that had befallen the country, and professing an earnest wish to grind them into powder with the heel of his boot.
Long before this he had been so loud in his professions of attachment to the South and its institutions, that he was regarded by her as the warmest friend she had north of Mason's and Dixon's. He had been much in the South--had been received and entertained with the greatest hospitality wherever he went — and had always expressed himself delighted to the point of ecstasy with his entertainers, their country, and their institutions.
He had held office under one Southern President, and been made a General in the Mexican war by another.
He now acts according to his instinct — as a Yankee, and it would be as unreasonable to blame a rattle make for biting as him for turning upon his friends.
He cannot help it. It is his nature as a Yankee, to be governed by expediency in all the transactions of life, and to take thought of principle only so far as it may be consistent with interest.
That interest, just now, can he best subserved by supporting the wise and humane policy of his Government, which consists in exciting Southern slaves to insurrection against their masters.
Let not the Southern admirers of Caleb feel chagrined.
While advising blood and age, he is but seeking some snug office for . We doubt whether Judas Iscariot was really a Jew. He must have been a Yankee.
At least, there are very few of that breed who would hesitate to sell their master, and throw in their worthless souls for a make- weight.
Caleb would willingly, see the blood of 300,000 men shed, provided he could turn a penny by it, and, provided, also, that he were exposed to no danger in the shedding of it.

Specie and Bank Notes.--Gold is firmer, but the brokers continue to sell at $2.30 premium.--Sliver has advanced to $2.20, but transactions are light.
Bank Notes are selling at 39@40 per cent. premium.
No demand for Sterling Exchange.

Bonds and Stocks.--The only change since our last report is a decline in State stock, sales having been made at 106½ and int. We quote Confederate bonds at 101½ and int., payable in now currency or par and int. payable in Treasury notes issued prior to 2d December last; Confederate bonds, (15 m. loan,) 109 and inst; Virginia Central Railroad bonds, 1st and 2d mort., 112 and int.; North Carolina sixes, 126@127½ Farmers' Bank stock, 107½.
Other stocks at last quotations.

Produce.--Wheat — We continue to quote $3.40@3.50 for prime qualities of red and white.
Core.--Last sales $4.25 bushel.
Flour — Superfine $20, Extra $22.50@23, Family $25 barrel, with an upward tendency.
Tobacco — Market firm; sales to-day, Lugs $10@15, Common Leaf $15@23, Fine Shipping $25@39, Fine Manufacturing $30@49, Bacon--$1@1.10 for horehound.
Apples--$30@45 per barrel, as to quality.
Butter--$1.50@2 18.
Lard $1.20. Cheese--$1.80. Dried Fruit--Apples $7@8 bushel; Peaches $12@15 bushel.
Beans--$7.50@9 bushel.
Onions--25@30 bushel.
Potatoes--Irish, $4.50 bushed; no Sweet in market.
Seeds — Clover, $26@28; Timothy, $7@8 bushel.
Tallow-- Candles--$1 by the box; retailing at $1.25. Corn Meal--$4@4.50 bushel.
Soap — 75c@81 18'.

Groceries, &c.--Sugar — Brown, 80@90a, by the barred; 75@85e by the hhd; White Clarified, $1.03 @1.20.
Molasses--$7.50@8 gallon.
Coffee--$3.25 @3.50 Tea — Black, $7@10; Gecen, $15@16.
Rice--10@12½c by the tierce, as to quality.
Salt — 25c Halls--$ ewt. Leather — Sole, $2@3.25; Herness, $3@3.25; Upper, Wax, and Russet, $4.50@5; Calf Skins, doe, $325@259.

div4.p: On the 14th February, at Halifax Court-House, H C, by the Rev. T G Lowe, Mr. A Zenter and Miss M J Ramkey, both of this city.
Petersburg and Danville papers please copy.
In Tappahannock, on the 16th inst., by Rev. H W L Temple, Capt. Robert H Tyler, 8th Va. Regiment, to Miss Sallie S Chine, of Prince Wm county, Va. *

in Manchester at the residence of Mrs. Eastwood, after a lingering illness of consumption, contracted in camp, Mr. Henry Marx, a native of Germany, and of company I, (Capt L F Bossieux,) 6th regiment Virginia volunteers, in the 25th year of his age.

lg.l: Weep no more, dear friends, for me,
Death claims me for its own;
I can no longer stay with thee,
For Jesus calls me home.

div4.p: The friends of Mrs Eastwood's family and his friends will attend his funeral from the Baptist Church, in Manchester, at 3 o'clock this (Wednesday) evening. [*] by his friends.
On Monday, the 16th instant, Mrs Rebecca Hogan, in the 52d year of her age.
Her funeral will take place to-day, from the residence of her brother-in-law, T B Anthony, on the corner of Broad and 2d sts. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend. *
On the 17th inst, Johanna, youngest daughter of Edward and Mary Rvan.
Her funeral will take place to-day, (Wednesday, the 18th inst,) from St. Peter's Church, about three o'clock. The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend. *

on the 28th of January, 1863, at 10 minutes past 11 P. M., at the residence of his grandfather, in Essex county, Va. Willie, the only child of Wm. W. (deceased) and Lucy a Cridlin, aged 1 year and 27 days.

lg.l: Alas! how changed that lovely flower,
which bloomed, and cheered my heart;
fair, fleeting comfort of an hour,
how soon we're called to part.
Yet dear Willie, we hope to meet thee,
When the day of life is fled;
Then in Heaven with joy to greet thee,
Where no farewell tear is shed. *

div4.p: Religions Herald please copy.
On Saturday morning, 14th inst., of typhoid fever, John L. Starke, eldest son of Sarah J. and Thomas J. Starke, of this city, aged 18 years and 4 months. *
In this city, Thursday evening, the 12th of Feb, at 6½ o'clock, Dr. A B Sutherland, in the 43d year of his age. *

div3.p: An Adjourned meeting of the Southern Dramatic Society will be held at the Broad Street Theatre this (Wednesday) evening, Feb. 18th, 1863, at 4 o'clock. A full attendance is particularly requested, as business of importance will be laid before the meeting.
div3.closer:
By order of the President.
J B Taylor, Sec'y. fe 18--1t*

div3.p:
Dr. O. Fairfax has removed to the house of Mr. Woodard, on Grace street, midway between 3d and 4th, on the North side.
During the day messages may be left either at his residence or at his office on 14th st., near the Ballard House.
After bed time, at the former place.
Dr. F. has decided to reside permanently in Richmond.

div3.head:
Office of the Roanoke Valley
R E Co, Clarksville, Va.
div3.p: A meeting of the stockholders of this Company will be held in the town of Clarksville on Thursday, the 19th day of March, 1863, and it is earnestly desired that a full attendance should be had.
div3.closer:
By order of the Board of Directors.
E A Williams, Sec'y. fe 14--2awt19thM

div3.head: Meeting of stockholders.
div3.p:
--A meeting of the stockholders of the Roanoke Valley Railroad Company will be held in the town of Clarksville, on Thursday, the 19th day of March, 1863.
A full meeting is desirable, as important business will be brought to the attention of the stockholders.
div3.closer:
By order of the Board.
E A Williams, Sec'y. fe 14--2awtd

div3.p:
I will pay a liberal reward for the arrest and delivery to me, or confinement in some jail so that I may get him, of my man Stokes, who left my house, in Amelia county, on the 18th of January, and is evidently attempting to make his escape to the Yankees, or has hired himself to work in some camp.
Stokes is about 23 years of age, 5 feet 6 or 8 inches high, black complexion, and has a large scar on his side, occasioned by a burn.
div3.closer:
Mary A Hardaway.
Deatonville P O Amelia co. fe 18--6t*

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed or stolen from my boat, at the corner of Byrd and 6th sts, on the night of the 9th inst., a dark iron gray horse, about 4 years old, with a black, short mane, and light (flaxen) fail at the end. He has a scar a ross his forehead about two inches long and also a scar on the inside of one of his hind legs, which has nearly healed up. He has quite a large neck, and also large legs and small body.
I will pay $50 reward for his return to McCarthy & Young's, corner of 6th and Byrd sts.

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on the 12th inst., a bright mulatto Girl, sixteen years old, named Bet. She is supposed to be lurking about the city.
I will give the above reward for her arrest and return to me, or confinement in jail, so that I get her.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay fifty dollars for the arrest and lodgment in a safe jail of my man George, if taken out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $20 reward if taken in those limits.
He left my house, in Manchester, on Saturday last, about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about six feet high; 23 years old; brown color, and weighs about 190 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock coat, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp, or try to get off on the canal.
He had on a good black hat.

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p:
--A negro Woman, superior nurse, stout constitution, and in unusually good health, though somewhat advanced in years.
Price $200. Address W L. Corbin, at this office.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p: --For the balance of the year, a young Woman, without encumbrance, a good washer and ironer, and dining-room servant.
div3.closer:
Wm. Beers.
No. 101 Main street. fe 18--ts

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--Upon reasonable terms, a capable negro Boy, of excellent qualities.
Apply at the Enquirer office.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A Woman, of excellent character, as Cook in a private family.
She is without encumbrance.
Also, a Girl, for Dining-room Servant or Nurse, who is honest and can be recommended in every respect.
Call on Grace at, two doors above Adams.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--I have for hire one superior Servant.
She is a good Cook, Washer and Ironer.
She can be found on Charity street, Duval's addition.
Apply to

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--I have an accomplished Cook, Washer and Ironer, with three children, who I will hire to a good home for food and clothing.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Mrs Ross,
On Franklin, bet. 6th and 7th sts. fe 14--eod3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Bugler--$2,000 will be paid for a Bugler, to go as a substitute in a first rate Artillery company, stationed near Dublin Depot, on the Va. and Tennessee Railroad.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Hughes, Caidwell & Co.
No. 9 Pearl st. fe 18--3t*

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To rent, by the month, one unfurnished Room suitable for chamber and one as kitchen, on Shockoe Hill, convenient to business.
Address "A.B." Box No. 552, Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Immediately, four or five young Ladies, to work at Dress Making.
Call at No. 28 Main street, over Bouis's Tin Store.
A good home and constant employment given.

div3.head: Wanted — a Clerk.
div3.p:
--One well acquainted with the settlement of Quartermasters' accounts.
None but experienced men need apply.--Address "P W." Gordonsville.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--In a Commission House, an active and intelligent Youth, who writes a fair hand--one of some experience preferred.
Address "Box 601"

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a single gentleman, a furnished Room, centrally located.
Address "Room 105. " Ballard House.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Nurse to attend a small-pox patient.
Apply to Dr. Furguson, Gen'l Hospital No. 10, (old United States Hotel.).

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--An Overseer, to take charge of an estate 100 miles above Richmond.--Satisfactory references will be required.
A single man preferred.
A liberal salary will be given — Also, a good boat Builder.
Address "Box 816," Richmond Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To rent, two furnished or unfurnished Rooms, or half of a House, with use of kitchen, between Cary and Leigh streets, and between Adams and 10th.
References given if required.
Address "A. W. D," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Virginia Lady, of some years' experience, desires a situation as Governess, or to take charge of a small school.
She is competent to teach the higher English branches, together with Latin and French.
Address "J M H," box 527.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An Engineer to run a saw mill a short distance from the city.
Apply at Dr. Chas E Anderson's, corner of Clay and Foushee sts.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For the balance of the war. For one over forty-five years of age, with reliable testimonials, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply, from 4 to 6 P. M. at the store No. 9 Fourteenth street, between Main and Cary.

div3.head: Substitute Notice.
div3.p: --A young man who can bring good testimonials, and who is free from conscription, is willing to go as Substitute in a stationary battery of heavy artillery. Price $8,000. Address "C A B" through the Post-Office, staring where an interview can be had.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in an infantry company, in the 11th Va. regiment, near Fredericksburg.
A good price will be paid for one who is over 45 years old, and can come with recommendation.
Call at 183 Broad street, between 5th and 6th.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45 years of age, to go in the cavalry service.
A liberal price will be paid.
Call at V T Crawford's Law Office, on Bank street, between 11th and 12th, between 9 and 12 o'clock A. M.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --Over 45 years old. For a reliable man, a fair price will be paid.--Apply to- morrow morning at the Richmond House, between 8 and 12 o'clock.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in a first class battery.
Highest cash price given.
Apply at the Saloon opposite the Spotswood Hotel, Main street.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For a good reliable man, $2,000 will be paid.
Apply at Briggs's Bakery, corner Broad and 4th sts.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in the 44th Virginia Regiment.
He must come well recommended and be over 45 years of age, for which a liberal price will be paid.
Call at Harvey, Hunt, James & Co's, on Virginia street, between the hours of 9 and 10 o'clock.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45 years of age with good recommendations.
A liberal price will be paid.
Call at Henningsen Hospital, room, No. 12. Wall st.

div3.head:
Camp of Infirmary Corps,
near King William Court House, Va.,
February 18th, 1863
div3.p: All absentees of this corps will report to me immediately, or I shall advertise them as deserters.

div3.head:
Camp 22d Va. Battalion,
Fields's Brigade, a P Hill's Division,
February 5th, 1863.
div3.p: Thirty Dollars reward.--A reward of $30 each will be paid for the arrest and the delivery to me of any one of the following named deserters:
Stepfano Couovick, an Italian, with very dark complexion, black eyes and hair, and about 5 feet 8 inches high; age, 28 years.
Augustus Kaiser, a German, with light complexion, blue eyes and light hair, about 5 feet 10 inches high, and 22 years of age.

J E Phelpss, Haile from Lynchburg, says he is a Kentuckian by birth, and was employed on the James River and Kanawha Canal for some time previous to enlistment; complexion dark, dark eyes and hair, 6 feet high, and about 24 years of age.
